description: fuser - identify processes using files or sockets

global_flags.description: all files specified on the command line.  By default, only files that are accessed by at least one process are shown.
in‐ odes  of  the specified file(s) and never on the file names even on network based file systems.
the  user  for confirmation before killing a process.  This option is silently ignored if -k is not present too.
This option must not be used with the -6 option and only has an effect with the tcp and udp  name‐ spaces.
This option must not be used with the  -4 option and only has an effect with the tcp and udp name‐ spaces.
a  mountpoint. This  is an invaluable seat belt which prevents you from killing the machine if NAME happens to not be a filesystem.

Unless changed with -SIGNAL, SIGKILL is sent.  An fuser process never kills itself,  but  may kill  other  fuser  processes.   The  effective  user  ID of the process executing fuser is set to its real user  ID  before  at‐ tempting to kill.

All processes accessing  files  on  that  file system are listed.  If a directory is specified, it is automati‐ cally  changed  to  NAME/  to  use any file system that might be mounted on that directory.

a  different  name  space.   The  name spaces file (file names, the default), udp (local UDP ports), and tcp  (local  TCP ports)  are supported.  For ports, either the port number or the symbolic name can be specified.  If there is no  ambiguity,  the shortcut notation name/space (e.g., 80/tcp) can be used.
operation.  -u and -v are ignored in this mode.  -a must not be used with -s.

mode.   Processes  are  shown  in a ps-like style.  The fields PID, USER and COMMAND are similar to  ps.   ACCESS  shows how  the process accesses the file.  Verbose mode will also show when a particular file is being accessed as a mount point,  knfs export  or  swap  file.  In this case kernel is shown instead of the PID.
Kill only processes which have write  access.   This  option  is silently ignored if -k is not present too.
the  specified  signal  instead  of  SIGKILL  when  killing processes.  Signals can be specified either by name (e.g., -HUP) or by number (e.g., -1).  This option is silently ignored if the
Same as -m option, used for POSIX compatibility.
Silently ignored, used for POSIX compatibility.
